newsitem.title: USA: Philippine president urges U.S. to extradite woman.
newsitem.headline: Philippine president urges U.S. to extradite woman.

text.p: Philippine President Fidel Ramos called on Washington on Wednesday to live up to a new extradition treaty and hand over a woman wanted in a multimillion dollar securities fraud in the Philippines.
Ramos, who was heading a trade delegation to California, also urged the United States to fulfil its promises to Filipinos who fought in the U.S. armed forces during the Second World War.
Asked at a news conference about the recently concluded U.S.-Philippine extradition treaty, Ramos said the agreement had been ratified by the Philippine legislature.
"In fact, the agreement is being tested now. We are asking for the extradition of a woman involved in a big bank fraud," he said. Aides identified the woman as Marilyn Nite.
"We have begun to implement it on our side; the United States must now do its part," said Ramos.
He acknowledged the situation had been complicated somewhat by the fact that Nite had married an American.

A spokeswoman for the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) in San Francisco said a woman she identified as Marilyn Hermosisima Nite, 39, had been arrested by INS agents on April 27 on a charge of overstaying her U.S. visa.
Nite was arrested in Newark, 20 miles (32 kms) southeast of San Francisco, INS spokeswoman Sharon Rummery said.

The Philippine government filed papers on Tuesday seeking Nite's extradition to face fraud charges, Rummery said. Nite, who was in custody, was due to appear before a U.S. Magistrate in Fresno on Friday, she said.

Nite, the former president of Bancapital Development Corp., an unlicensed dealer in government securities, was one of four people charged with fraud in the Philippines in 1994 in connection with a Philippine Treasury bill scandal.
The four were accused of defrauding the Bank of Commerce of $6 million worth of undelivered T-bills.
In a wide-ranging news conference at the Los Angeles City Hall, Ramos was also asked about the status of Philippine Second World War veterans.

"Filipino veterans who served in the U.S. Army were promised everything while they were fighting -- justice, just like other GI's for defending the Pacific," he said. "But they did not get that from the United States."
However, he said, "there is growing momentum in (the U.S.) Congress of support for them."
He was referring to the Filipino Veterans Equity Bill which is still in the early stages of committee debate in both the Senate and the House of Representatives.
Under the bill, Philippine veterans would be granted the same pension, benefits and health care given American military veterans.
"There are about 75,000 of them. They are getting older and weaker and many are probably not going to survive longer on this Earth," said Ramos. "We are hoping and praying for them."
